<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 751, 89]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the motion of an oscillating metre rule.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 120]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 134, 816, 323]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 343, 532, 361]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 375, 144, 393]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 375, 920, 408]]<|/det|>
Ensure that the metre rule is horizontal. You may need to adjust the height of one of the clamps slightly.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 421, 920, 454]]<|/det|>
Briefly describe how you check that the metre rule is horizontal. You may draw a diagram or add to Fig. 1.1 if it helps to explain your answer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 606, 920, 625]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 638, 725, 656]]<|/det|>
Do not change the length \(l\) of the threads during the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 670, 146, 687]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 670, 920, 701]]<|/det|>
Move one thread to the \(40.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the metre rule and one thread to the \(60.0 \text{cm}\) mark on the metre rule. The distance \(d\) between the threads is \(20.0 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 715, 584, 732]]<|/det|>
Move the stands so that the threads remain vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 745, 920, 778]]<|/det|>
Hold each end of the metre rule. Twist the metre rule a small amount, as shown in Fig. 1.2, and then let it go so that it oscillates in a rotating motion.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 792, 863, 887]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 908, 534, 926]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 880, 88]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in Table 1.1, the time \(t\) for 5 complete oscillations of the metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|> Repeat this procedure for \(d\) values of 30.0 cm, 40.0 cm, 50.0 cm and 60.0 cm. For each value, the threads must be at equal distances either side of the 50.0 cm mark on the metre rule. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 149, 541, 166]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[301, 175, 695, 345]]<|/det|>
\(d/\mathrm {cm}\)\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(\frac {1}{T}/\frac {1}{\mathrm {s}}\)
20.0
30.0
40.0
50.0
60.0
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 345, 920, 363]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 377, 144, 395]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 373, 920, 410]]<|/det|> For each value of the distance \(d\), calculate and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(\frac{1}{T}\) where \(T\) is the time for 1 oscillation of the metre rule. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 403, 690, 428]]<|/det|> Use your values of time \(t\) from Table 1.1 and the equation \(\frac{1}{T} = \frac{5}{t}\) . <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 424, 920, 442]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 454, 146, 472]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 448, 648, 477]]<|/det|> Plot a graph of distance \(d / \text{cm}\) (y-axis) against \(\frac{1}{T} / \frac{1}{\text{s}}\) (x-axis). <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[253, 483, 744, 828]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 833, 920, 851]]<|/det|> [4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(e)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[573, 147, 918, 166]]<|/det|>
<form>G = .................................................... [1]

<label>(f)</label>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 180, 920, 214]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 319, 181, 338]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 92, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 803, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the cooling of hot water in two different cups. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 122]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 2.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[84, 131, 856, 320]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 336, 532, 354]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 367, 144, 386]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 367, 185, 386]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 367, 420, 386]]<|/det|> Remove the lid from cup A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 397, 648, 416]]<|/det|> Pour \(75 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into cup A and replace the lid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 429, 562, 447]]<|/det|> Place the thermometer in the water in cup A. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 459, 920, 494]]<|/det|> In the first row of Table 2.1, record the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at time \(t = 0\) and immediately start the stop-clock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 505, 920, 540]]<|/det|> Record, in Table 2.1, the temperature \(\theta\) of the water at times \(t = 30 \text{s}, 60 \text{s}, 90 \text{s}, 120 \text{s}, 150 \text{s}\) and \(180 \text{s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 537, 920, 556]]<|/det|> [1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 567, 180, 586]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 567, 487, 586]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps in (a)(i) for cup B. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 567, 920, 586]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 598, 146, 617]]<|/det|> <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 599, 541, 617]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 625, 752, 851]]<|/det|>
cup Acup B
\(t/\)\(\theta /\)\(\theta /\)
0
30
60
90
120
150
180
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 868, 455, 887]]<|/det|> Complete the headings in Table 2.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 868, 920, 887]]<|/det|> [1]

<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 72, 918, 106]]<|/det|>
Write a conclusion stating which cup, A or B, is the more effective in reducing the cooling rate of the hot water in this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 117, 552, 136]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 242, 920, 260]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 272, 920, 305]]<|/det|>
Calculate \(x_{\mathrm{A}}\), the average cooling rate for cup A over the whole experiment. Use your readings for cup A from Table 2.1 and the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[432, 310, 561, 339]]<|/det|>
\[x_{\mathrm{A}} = \frac{\theta_{0} - \theta_{180}}{T}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 350, 920, 384]]<|/det|>
where \(T = 180 \text{s}\) and \(\theta_0\) and \(\theta_{180}\) are the temperatures at time \(t = 0\) and at time \(t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit for the cooling rate.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[569, 427, 920, 446]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a resistor and a lamp connected in series. The circuit has been set up for you with the voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference across the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 576, 152]]<|/det|>
Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[180, 165, 787, 539]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 555, 532, 573]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 144, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 586, 183, 604]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 586, 282, 604]]<|/det|>
Switch on.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 617, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
Move the crocodile clip on the resistance wire so that the value of the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) across the lamp is 2.0V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 664, 920, 696]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the value of the current \(I\) for the lamp and resistor in series.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 711, 920, 743]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter and re-connect it so that it measures the potential difference across the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 757, 920, 789]]<|/det|>
Measure, and record in Table 3.1, the value of the potential difference \(V_{\mathrm{R}}\) across the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 804, 282, 821]]<|/det|>
Switch off.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 835, 863, 852]]<|/det|>
Disconnect the voltmeter and re-connect it in its original position across the lamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 850, 920, 868]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 72, 181, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 641, 91]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps in **(a)**(i) for \(V_{\mathrm{L}} = 1.0 \text{V}\) and \(V_{\mathrm{L}} = 0.5 \text{V}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 72, 920, 90]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 128, 789, 233]]<|/det|>

each value of \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 316, 725, 345]]<|/det|> Use your values of \(V_{\mathrm{L}}\) and \(I\) from Table 3.1 and the equation \(R_{\mathrm{L}} = <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 636, 89]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the motion of a ball rolling down a slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 920, 136]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment which enables him to investigate how **one** factor affects the average speed of the ball.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 150, 557, 167]]<|/det|>
Average speed can be calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[358, 173, 653, 203]]<|/det|>
\[\text{average speed} = \frac{\text{distance travelled}}{\text{time taken}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 520, 244]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out the experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 258, 398, 275]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 303, 440, 320]]<|/det|>
a board which can act as a slope

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 319, 480, 336]]<|/det|>
blocks to support one end of the board.
